questions.text: A “motorcyclist fracture," typically results from what type of impact?
questions.explanation:
Ring Fracture

Motorcyclist Fracture (Hinge Fracture)
  • Encircles the foramen magnum at the skull base.
  • Runs from the sella turcica to the petrous ridges and posterior fossa.
  • It can extend to the middle ear and roof of the nose.
  • Transverse fracture at the skull base, splitting it and creating a "hinge" - nodding face sign.
  • It extends from one petrous ridge across the sella turcica to the other petrous ridge.

Caused by: (Option B, C and D ruled out)

  • Falls landing on feet/buttocks (force transmitted through the spine).
  • Heavy blows to the top of the skull/ vertex.
  • Twisting of the head on the spine.
  • Blows to the occiput or chin.

Often caused by side impacts.

(Option A)


 

Ring fracture

Hinge fracture

questions.text: Which type of fracture is most commonly associated with seat belt injuries in motor vehicle accidents?
Which among the following are usually associated with collisions over the dashboard during an RTA? 1) Posterior cruciate ligament injury 2) Posterior dislocation of hip 3) Patella fracture
questions.explanation:
Affected
  • Front seat passenger (hip and knees flexed position)

3 Ps
  • Patella fracture
  • Posterior cruciate ligament injury
  • Posterior hip dislocation

Other injuries
  • Fracture - pelvis/femur
  • Most common nerve injured: Sciatic nerve

questions.text: What is the most likely structure to be affected in this illustration shown?
questions.explanation:
Patterned contusion (known as Seat belt sign)
  • Drivers: starts from the right shoulder
  • Passengers: starts from the left shoulder


 

Intra-abdominal (deceleration- compression)
  • Mesentery - most commonly affected (Option B)
  • Small intestine: DJ flexure (primary),Ileocaecal junction (secondary)
  • Liver, Spleen

Vertebral injuries (distraction- compression)
  • Distraction(separation of joint): seen on posterior side
  • Compression: seen on anterior side
  • Chance fracture: fracture involving all 3 columns of spine

Seat belt syndrome
  • Seat belt sign + intra-abdominal injuries + vertebral injuries

questions.text: Person sustained a blow to the front of the chest by the steering wheel in an RTA. Which site of the aorta is most likely to be affected?

options.label: A
options.text: Ascending aorta - 1.5cms proximal to ligamentum arteriosum

options.label: B
options.text: Ascending aorta - 1.5cms distal to ligamentum arteriosum

options.label: C
options.text: Descending aorta - 1.5cms proximal to ligamentum arteriosum

options.label: D
options.text: Descending aorta - 1.5cms distal to ligamentum arteriosum

questions.correct_answer: D. Descending aorta - 1.5cms distal to ligamentum arteriosum
questions.explanation:
Sites affected
  • Sternum/Ribs (Flail chest)
  • Chest (patterned bruises seen)
  • Elbow/forearm (pressure transmission effect)

Aorta
  • Intimal tears in aorta (either partial or complete).
  • Site: 1.5cms distal to ligamentum arteriosum (junction of aortic arch with descending aorta) (Option D)
  • Multiple parallel intimal tears near the main transection is known as Ladder rung tears.
  • Osseous punch: compression of aorta between sternum and thoracic vertebra.

Other organs involved
  • Heart: Hemopericardium -> Cardiac tamponade
  • Lungs: Pincer contusions seen
  • Liver > Spleen

questions.text: What is the mechanism of injury and common level affected in fracture-dislocation seen with whiplash injury
questions.explanation:
Mechanism
  • Acceleration: hyperextension followed by hyperflexion
  • Deceleration: hyperflexion followed by hyperextension

Associated injuries
  • Atlanto-axial dislocation > C5-C6 fracture-dislocation
  • Anterior longitudinal ligament and cervical ligaments are torn

Passenger
  • Most commonly front seat passenger is affected

Prevention
  • Use of head restraints (head rest) prevents hyperextension of neck

questions.text: Windshield impact to front seat passenger may impact which among the following injuries
questions.explanation:
Sparrow foot marks
  • Multiple, small, punctate facial lacerations due to shattered glass pieces.
  • Mechanism: Driver/passenger ramming onto the glass.
  • Site: Predominantly over the face
  • More specific for windshield injuries.

Dicing injury
  • More common than sparrow foot marks
  • Multiple superficial cuts over the skin.
  • Mechanism: Glass pieces falling towards the person.
  • Site: All over the face and body
  • Can also occur in rear seat passengers

Other injuries
  • Avulsion of forehead skin
  • Basilar skull fractures
  • Fracture-dislocation

questions.text: Which of the following is a frequent type of injury seen in tertiary impact injuries?
Which of the following is a classic pattern of injury seen in pedestrian children involved in road traffic accidents?
questions.explanation:
Injuries
  • Occur when the victim is struck by the vehicle, often following recognizable patterns.
  • Common injuries include abrasions, lacerations, fractures of legs, thighs, or buttocks, and fractures of the fibula and tibia.
  • When an adult is hit by a car, the impact is often at knee level, and injuries vary depending on the victim’s position and vehicle orientation.
  • Common cause of death is due to head injury and fracture dislocation of cervical spine, mainly at the atlanto-occipital joint.

Factors influencing injury behavior include
  • Position of the victim's feet (whether they were firmly placed or raised at impact).
  • Speed of the vehicle (low speed results in being thrown onto the bonnet; at higher speeds, the victim is projected or scooped up).
  • Road surface type (smooth, rough, gravel).
  • Point of impact relative to the center of gravity.
  • When the pedestrian is knocked down from behind with both feet fixed to the ground, there will be fracture of the bones of the lower limbs.

Waddell's Triad

A classic pattern in pedestrian children struck by vehicles.

  • Fractured femoral shaft.
  • Intrathoracic or intra-abdominal injuries.
  • Contralateral head injury.

Injury Behavior Based on Position and Vehicle Impact

On Being struck from behind with feet not firmly on the ground:

  • The victim’s feet are thrown backwards.
  • Possible head injuries from striking against the windscreen.
  • Victims can be scooped up or fall to one side, sustaining further head injuries from striking the ground.

 

Struck from the front:

  • Injuries to chest, abdomen, with potential fractures of ribs or vertebrae.
  • Pelvic or sacroiliac fractures, as well as fractures of the tibia or fibula from bumper impact.
 

Bumper impact injuries:

  • Soft tissue damage and fractures (typically wedge-shaped).
  • Fractures may suggest the point of impact and movement direction of the vehicle.
  • The location and measurement of the bumper fracture on the victim provide details about the vehicle's height and speed.
  • Wedge type bumper fracture of the tibia seen.

 
  • Marks may suggest if the victim was walking or lying on the road when struck.
 

When the pedestrian walks into the side of a moving vehicle

  • Glancing abrasions
  • Crushing lacerations on the side or front of the face, chest and arms.
  • Fracture of ribs with or without laceration.
  • Sustain secondary injuries
  • Fracture of the skull occurs due to direct impact of the vehicle on the head.

questions.text: What is a unique type of injury often associated with motorcyclists?

A retired boxer presents with a gradual decline in his coordination, memory, and speech over the past few years. His wife reports personality changes, including paranoia and social withdrawal. O/E, he displays dysarthria and broad-based gait. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25 year old man is brought to the ED after a fall from a height. He was unconscious upon arrival, and a CT scan was done which revealed the following. What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery

questions.correct_answer: B. Rupture of the middle meningeal artery

questions.text: In the context of intracranial haemorrhages, which of the following statements accurately describes the relationship between the layers of the cranial anatomy and the associated blood vessels?

options.label: A
options.text: The epidural space contains bridging veins.

options.label: B
options.text: The subdural space is located between the pia mater and the arachnoid mater.

options.label: C
options.text: The subarachnoid space contains arteries of the circle of Willis.

options.label: D
options.text: The middle meningeal artery is located between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater.

questions.correct_answer: C. The subarachnoid space contains arteries of the circle of Willis.
questions.explanation:
Space

Location

Blood vessel involved

Epidural Space

Between the skull vault and dura mater. The collection of blood here leads to epidural hematoma.

Middle meningeal artery

(Option D ruled out)

Subdural Space

Between the arachnoid and dura mater. The collection of blood here leads to subdural hematoma. (Option B ruled out)

Bridging veins (which drain into the dural venous sinus)

(Option A ruled out)

Subarachnoid Space

Between the arachnoid and pia mater

Arteries of the circle of Willis (Middle cerebral artery, Anterior communicating artery -most commonly) (Option C)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with facial trauma after being struck in the eye during a sports accident. Which radiographic finding is most indicative of a blowout fracture of the orbit?

options.label: D
options.text: Circular crack around the skull base

questions.text: In which type of hanging is the knot positioned at the nape of the neck?

A 32 year old male is brought to the emergency after sustaining a gunshot wound to the head during a robbery. The bullet trajectory is reported as oblique. Which type of skull fracture is most commonly associated with this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Depressed Fracture

Comminuted Fracture

Gutter Fracture
  • Occurs when a fragment of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain.
  • Caused by blows from heavy objects with a small surface (e.g., hammers, bricks). (Option A ruled out)
  • The shape of the depressed area may resemble the object that caused the injury.

Variants:

  • Elevated Fracture: One end of the fractured fragment is raised above the skull, while the other is pushed inward. Caused by sharp objects like an axe. (Option D ruled out)
  • Pond Fracture: Seen in infants, this smooth depression occurs without a fracture line, resembling a dent in a ping-pong ball. Caused by obstetrics forceps blade.
  • Involves multiple intersecting fracture lines, breaking the bone into several fragments.
  • Caused by high-impact trauma (e.g., vehicular accidents, crushing injuries). (Option C ruled out)
  • It may occur alongside other fractures (e.g., fissured or depressed fractures).
  • Spider web-like patterns on an X-ray are characteristic of comminuted fractures.
  • In severe cases, bone fragments may penetrate the brain or become displaced.
  • A groove or channel is formed in the skull bone, often due to an oblique bullet wound. (Option B)
  • Frequently associated with comminuted and depressed fractures of the inner skull table.
  • Bone fragments can cause injury to the meninges or brain.

Depressed fracture

Comminuted fracture

Gutter fracture

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is a diastatic skull fracture most likely to occur?

options.label: A
options.text: An adult hit by a broad surface object

options.label: B
options.text: A child with increased intracranial pressure

options.label: C
options.text: A teenager experiencing a sports-related injury

options.label: D
options.text: An elderly person falling onto their buttocks

questions.correct_answer: B. A child with increased intracranial pressure
questions.explanation:
Fissured Fracture (Linear Fracture)

Diastatic Fracture (Sutural Fracture)

  • The most common skull fracture accounts for about 70% of cases.
  • Linear cracks may involve the vertex or skull base. It can affect the full thickness of the bone or just the inner/outer layers.
  • The fracture line is irregular and fine, sometimes hard to detect on X-rays. It runs parallel to the compressive force.
  • No depression of bone fragments.
  • Involves the separation of cranial sutures.
  • More common in children.
  • Often occurs with other skull fractures, especially fissured fractures.
  • Commonly seen at the sagittal suture.

Causes:

  • Impact against broad surfaces (e.g., falls or road traffic accidents). (Option A ruled out)
  • Falls on feet or buttocks, transmitting force upwards. (Option D ruled out)

Causes:

  • Blunt trauma to the head.
  • Increased intracranial pressure leads to suture separation. (Option B)

Narrow fissure skull fracture

questions.text: What is the most commonly fractured bone in cases of basilar skull fractures?
questions.explanation:
Thickness of skull bones
 

Male

Female

Frontal

7.8 mm

8.6 mm

Parietal

9.6 mm

10.1 mm

Occipital

10.1 mm

10 mm

Temporal

6 mm

6 mm

Temporal bone fracture

Longitudinal Temporal Bone Fracture

Transverse Temporal Bone Fracture
  • The most common type (70-90% of temporal bone fractures).
  • Runs parallel to the long axis of the petrous temporal bone.
  • Otic Capsule is spared.
  • Conductive hearing loss due to ossicle involvement and tympanic membrane involvement.
  • Facial nerve involvement occurs in about 25% of cases.
  • Less common (10-30% of temporal bone fractures).
  • Extends perpendicular to the petrous temporal bone's long axis.
  • Otic Capsule is involved, leading to sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Ossicles and tympanic membranes are generally unaffected.
  • Higher incidence of facial nerve involvement.

questions.text: A forensic pathologist examines a drowning victim’s dead body and conducts tests for diatoms and chloride levels in the heart. The victim was found in a lake, and a water sample from the scene was collected for analysis. Which of the following statements is false ?

options.label: A
options.text: In freshwater drowning, chloride levels in the left heart are lower.

options.label: B
options.text: In saltwater drowning, chloride levels in the left heart are higher.

options.label: C
options.text: Finding diatoms in bone marrow indicates that the individual ingested water while alive.

options.label: D
options.text: The absence of diatoms in tissues can definitively rule out drowning.

questions.correct_answer: D. The absence of diatoms in tissues can definitively rule out drowning.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Diatom Test

Gettler Test

Features
  • Diatoms are microscopic unicellular algae with silicon skeletons that are chemically inert and resistant to strong acids.
  • In antemortem drowning, diatoms enter the bloodstream through ruptured alveolar walls, reaching organs like the lungs, heart, brain, liver, and bone marrow.
  • Diatoms resist putrefaction, making the test useful even in decomposed bodies.
  • A 50g tissue sample is treated with nitric acid and examined for diatoms.
    • A water sample from the drowning site is collected for comparison of diatom species and proportions.
  • Limitations: Possible contamination from food, air, or environment.
    • The test cannot rule out contamination, but it is still the "gold standard" for diagnosing typical drowning.
  • Normal Chloride Levels: The chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart is typically similar, around 600 mg/100 ml.
  • A 25 mg% or more difference in chloride levels between the two sides suggests antemortem drowning.

Interpretation
  • Presence: Finding diatoms in tissues (bone marrow, blood, etc.) strongly indicates antemortem drowning, suggesting the individual inhales diatom-rich water. Detection in multiple tissues enhances reliability, indicating systemic absorption and confirming drowning. (Option C ruled out)
  • Absence: While the absence of diatoms does not rule out drowning, it raises questions about the death's circumstances. Prior water ingestion or contact with diatom-rich environments could allow diatoms to enter circulation without drowning.
  • Freshwater Drowning: The chloride content in the left heart is lower than in the right heart due to dilution from the water. (Option A ruled out)
  • Saltwater Drowning: In saltwater drowning, the chloride content in the left heart is higher than in the right heart due to hemoconcentration and mixing with saltwater. (Option B ruled out)
  • No Change in Chloride Content: Observed in deaths from laryngeal spasm, vagal inhibition, putrefaction, patent foramen ovale, or when the saline content of the drowning medium is similar to that of blood.

questions.text: Match the following signs of drowning. 1. Sehrt's Sign a) Free liquid in the paranasal sinus. 2. Sveshnikov's sign b) Water in the middle ear due to violent respiratory efforts while drowning. 3. Sabinsky's Sign c) Micro rupture in gastric mucosa due to stretching. 4. Ueno's Sign d) Small and anaemic spleen due to vasoconstriction.
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:

Signs in Drowning

Sehrt's Sign

Micro rupture in gastric mucosa due to over-stretching on ingestion of fluid.

Sveshnikov's sign

Free liquid in the paranasal sinus.

Sabinsky's Sign

Small and anemic spleen due to vasoconstriction.

Ueno's Sign

Water in the middle ear due to violent respiratory efforts while drowning.

Wydler's Sign

Gastric content in a container with three layers (Foam- top, liquid- middle, solid- bottom).

Drowning Index

Weight of both lungs + weight of pleural effusion / Weight of spleen

If > 14.1%, it suggests AM drowning.

questions.text: A forensic pathologist is conducting an autopsy on a body recovered from a body of water. During the examination, several findings are noted. Based on the following statements regarding postmortem findings in drowning, which of the following is true? Frothy fluid, resulting from the churning of water, mucus, and air, is present at the mouth and nostrils, indicating drowning. Cutis anserina indicates prolonged immersion in warm water. Washerwoman’s hand appears as wrinkled and sodden skin due to prolonged submersion. A cadaveric spasm is the immediate stiffening of muscles holding debris, indicating drowning. Paltauf’s hemorrhage is a postmortem finding not associated with drowning. Water and bleeding in the middle ear confirm antemortem drowning. The heart shows equal amounts of blood on both sides in drowning victims.
questions.explanation:
PM Findings in Drowning

External Findings

Internal Findings

Pale & cyanosed face from putrefaction.

 

Eyes half-open/closed, suffused conjunctiva, dilated pupils, subconjunctival hemorrhages (Antemortem drowning).

 

Froth: Fine, copious, tenacious, lathery froth at mouth and nostrils is characteristic of antemortem drowning, and reappears after wiping or chest pressure.

  • Mechanism: The churning of water, mucus, and retained air in airways creates froth. (Statement 1)
  • In other conditions like strangulation, and electric shock, the froth is not as fine or tenacious.
 

Cutis anserina (goose flesh): The puckered appearance of skin due to the contraction of erector muscles in cold water, occurs immediately after antemortem submersion or by rigor mortis. (Statement 2)

 

Washerwomen’s hand: Wrinkled, sodden, and bleached appearance of hands and feet due to prolonged submersion, occurring postmortem in 3–4 hours and fully affecting the hands by 24 hours. (Statement 3)

 

Cadaveric spasm: Immediate stiffening of muscles holding grass, sand, or debris in clenched hands—antemortem proof of drowning. (Statement 4)

 

Rigor mortis appears early after a violent struggle (Antemortem drowning).

Lungs: Ballooning with frothy fluid, rib indentations, heavy and waterlogged.

  • Paltauf's hemorrhage: Red-gray mottling with areas of hemorrhage due to effusion of blood along interlobular septa. (Statement 5)
 

Heart: Right side full of dark venous blood, left side empty (a sign of asphyxia). (Statement 7)

  • Gettler test: Measures chloride content to differentiate antemortem drowning.
    • Freshwater: Lower chloride in the left heart.
    • Saltwater: Higher chloride in the left heart.
 

Stomach: Water is present in 70% of cases, indicating antemortem drowning if liquid was not swallowed voluntarily.

 

Brain: Congested with softened grey-white junction (Antemortem).

 

Middle ear: The presence of water and bleeding in the middle ear confirms antemortem drowning. (Statement 6)

 

Diatom test: The presence of diatoms in lungs and bone marrow suggests antemortem drowning.

questions.text: Which of the following methods of suffocation is most commonly associated with a reflex vagal inhibition that can lead to sudden cardiac arrest?
questions.explanation:
Methods of Suffocation

Features

Smothering

(Option A ruled out)
  • Definition: Closing the nose and mouth using hands or foreign substances (e.g., mud, cloth).
  • Autopsy Findings:
    • External: Pallor may be present around the mouth/nose, pressure marks, distinct nail marks, petechiae, contusion on the inner lip, and stains on the bedding.
    • Internal: Potential internal organ haemorrhages.

Gagging (Option B ruled out)
  • Definition: Asphyxia caused by a cloth or material obstructing the mouth and nose.
  • Mechanism: A gag can block the pharynx, initially allowing nasal airflow. Obstruction worsens due to saliva and mucus, leading to complete airway blockage.
  • Symptoms:
    • Facial congestion.
    • Fine petechiae on the face, sclerae, and conjunctivae.
  • Intent: Always homicidal.

Choking

(Option C ruled out)
  • Definition: Airway obstruction due to an object lodged in the hypopharynx.
  • Accidental Choking: Often occurs during meals, especially while laughing or crying; vomited matter may be inhaled under intoxication or unconsciousness.
  • Immediate Symptoms: Acute respiratory distress; complications may develop later.
  • Autopsy Findings:
    • Thickened epiglottis and folds
    • Mucus accumulation in the throat.
    • Lungs exhibit interalveolar oedema, congestion, and haemorrhages.

Café Coronary
  • Definition: Sudden collapse and death while eating, often in intoxicated individuals.
  • Symptoms:
    • Cyanosis and violent coughing.
    • Collapse without significant distress.
  • Cause of Death: Reflex vagal inhibition leading to sudden cardiac arrest; high blood alcohol content anaesthetises the gag reflex. A poorly chewed food bolus may obstruct the larynx.
  • Autopsy Findings: Obstruction may be found in the mouth, larynx, or trachea, with food particles in mucus in the trachea/bronchi, differentiating from cases of post-mortem oesophagal food forcing. Signs of asphyxia may be absent.

  • Treatment: Heimlich Maneuver: Stand behind the patient, interlock fingers, and apply pressure to the stomach.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the given image is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It can cause death through asphyxia and vagal inhibition, requiring at least 2 minutes of pressure.

options.label: B
options.text: Results in minimal visible injuries on the neck.

options.label: C
options.text: Key postmortem findings include only superficial bruises and no internal injuries.

questions.correct_answer: A. It can cause death through asphyxia and vagal inhibition, requiring at least 2 minutes of pressure.
questions.explanation:
Examination Type

Findings

External Examination

(Option B ruled out)
  • Bruises and Abrasions: On the front and sides of the neck.
  • Signs of Asphyxia: Cyanosis, facial swelling, Tardieu's spots, bleeding from nose and ears.
  • Injuries on Other Body Parts: Additional signs of violence (abrasions, bruises, scratches).

Internal Examination (Option C ruled out)
  • Haemorrhages: In subcutaneous tissues under bruises.
  • Muscle Damage: Tears or lacerations in neck muscles.
  • Hyoid Bone Fracture: Significant diagnostic indicator, typically from inward compression.
  • Laryngeal and Tracheal Damage: Fractures of thyroid and potentially cricoid cartilages.
  • Haemorrhages in Mouth/Throat: Bruising and lacerations on the tongue, haemorrhages in mucous membranes.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most characteristic of ligature strangulation?

options.label: A
options.text: Distinct bruising of subcutaneous tissues beneath the ligature

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of Tardieu's spots primarily on the chest and abdomen

options.label: D
options.text: Absence of postmortem staining above the ligature

questions.correct_answer: A. Distinct bruising of subcutaneous tissues beneath the ligature
questions.explanation:
Finding

Description

Face
  • Congested, swollen, and cyanosed.
  • Tardieu's spots (petechiae) on the forehead, temples, eyelids, and conjunctiva. (Option B ruled out)
  • Prominent eyes with congested conjunctiva, dilated pupils, and possible subconjunctival haemorrhages.
  • Cyanosis of lips, fingernails, and earlobes.
  • Postmortem staining above the ligature. (Option D ruled out)
  • Swollen, dark-coloured, protruding tongue, possibly bitten.
  • Bloodstained frothy fluid and mucus in mouth and nostrils.

Neck
  • Ligature mark ('furrow'): well-defined groove, typically the same width as the ligature, often horizontal.
  • More prominent on the front and sides of the neck.
  • Red base with congested or ecchymosed margins; imprint pattern may be present.
  • Can be indistinct if the ligature is soft; it may appear as a deep groove with a narrow cord ('cheese cutter method').
  • May show an oblique appearance if the victim was dragged post-strangulation.

Other Body Parts
  • Deep, prominent postmortem staining.
  • Involuntary discharge of urine and faecal matter; less common seminal ejaculation.
  • Clenched hands; possible genital turgidity.
  • Possible abrasions, fingernail marks, and contusions on face, and arms, indicating struggle.
  • Horizontal, irregular abrasions on the neck may indicate attempts to remove ligature.

Feature

Hanging

Strangulation

Face

Usually, pale, petechiae are less common

Congested, livid with petechiae

Tongue swelling and protrusion

Less marked

More marked

Bleeding from nose, ears, mouth

Less common

More common

Ligature mark ('furrow')

  • Direction
  • Continuity
  • Level in the neck
  • Base
  • Oblique
  • Noncontinuous
  • Above thyroid
  • Pale, hard, parchment-like
  • Transverse
  • Continuous
  • Below thyroid
  • Soft and reddish

Abrasions and ecchymoses about the edges of the mark

Not common

Common

Involuntary discharge of feces and urine

Less common

More common

Involuntary discharge of seminal fluid

More common

Less common

Bruising of neck muscles

Less common

More common

Subcutaneous tissue under the mark

White, hard, glistening

Ecchymosed

Hyoid bone fracture

May occur

Uncommon

Thyroid fracture

Unlikely

More common

Larynx and trachea fracture

Unlikely

May be found

Emphysematous bullae on lungs

Sometimes present

Very common

Carotid arteries

Damage may be seen in the intima

Rare

Design

History of previous unsuccessful attempts of suicide may be available

No such history is available

Signs of struggle

Absent

Always present, unless taken unaware

questions.text: What is a common characteristic of sexual asphyxia that differentiates it from judicial hanging?

options.label: B
options.text: Use of elaborate setups and self-release mechanisms

questions.correct_answer: B. Use of elaborate setups and self-release mechanisms
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Description

Asphyxia Mechanism

Both involve asphyxia caused by a ligature around the neck.

External Findings

May include a ligature mark, cyanosis, and petechiae.

Aspect

Sexual Asphyxia (Autoerotic Asphyxia)

Judicial Hanging

Intent (Option A ruled out)

Achieve sexual gratification; death is accidental.

Capital punishment; is intended to cause death.

Execution

Involves elaborate setups, bondage, and self-release mechanisms. (Option B)

Highly controlled; specific knot placement (submental) and calculated drop height.

Injuries

Usually less severe; aims to induce hypoxia without fatal damage.

Designed to cause rapid death through forceful cervical spine fracture (hangman‘s fracture-spondylolisthesis of C2 over C3).

Ligature Mark (Option D ruled out)

May be less prominent due to padding; often not distinctive.

Typically distinct, located below the chin or ear.

Cervical Spine Fracture (Option C ruled out)

Rarely occurs.

A hallmark feature.

Scene Findings

Evidence of sexual activity is often present.

Takes place in a controlled environment; no signs of sexual activity.

questions.text: A forensic team is called to investigate a case of judicial hanging in an obese individual. The victim was found suspended from a significant height with the knot positioned at the back of the neck. During the autopsy, a transverse tear in the carotid artery is observed, consistent with a long drop hanging. Which of the following findings is most likely associated with this case?
Which of the following is NOT a cause of early death in hanging?

Match the following neck structure compressed with their respective pressures needed to cause death in hanging. 1.Jugular Veins a) 10 kg 2.Carotid Arteries b) 30 kg 3.Trachea c) 2 kg 4.Vertebral Arteries d) 15 kg
questions.explanation:
Neck structure compressed

Compression Pressure

Result

Jugular Veins

2 kg

Venous congestion leading to cessation of cerebral circulation

Carotid Arteries

2.5 - 10 kg

Cerebral anemia/ anoxia

Trachea

15 kg

Asphyxia

Vertebral Arteries

8 - 30 kg

Cerebral anemia/ anoxia
